title: Archery Vocabulary
description: Take aim at this quiz about archery terms and techniques!

questions.question: In archery, what is a 'quiver'?
options: A scoring zone on the target
A container used to hold arrows
A type of bowstring
The act of shaking while aiming
questions.explanation: A quiver is a container designed to hold arrows, worn on the back, hip, or attached to the bow, keeping arrows organized and readily accessible for shooting.

questions.question: What is the 'nock' in archery?
options: The handle of the bow
A knocking sound when the arrow hits the target
The grooved fitting on the end of an arrow that clips onto the bowstring
A type of arrowhead
questions.explanation: The nock is the slotted plastic or horn fitting at the rear end of an arrow that clips onto the bowstring, ensuring the arrow stays in position until released.

questions.question: In archery, what is the 'bullseye'?
options: A type of arrow tip
The center of the target, worth the most points
A type of bow
A technique for aiming
questions.explanation: The bullseye is the innermost circle of the target, typically worth the highest score (10 points in standard target archery), colored gold or yellow.

questions.question: What does 'draw weight' refer to in archery?
options: How heavy the target is
The weight of the arrow
The weight of the bow itself
The force required to pull the bowstring back to full draw
questions.explanation: Draw weight is the amount of force (measured in pounds) needed to pull the bowstring back to the full draw length, affecting arrow speed and penetration.

questions.question: In archery, what is 'anchor point'?
options: The spot where the bow rests on the ground
The center point of the bowstring
Where the target is anchored to the stand
A consistent reference point on the face where the drawing hand is placed at full draw
questions.explanation: The anchor point is a consistent spot on the archer's face (such as the corner of the mouth or chin) where the drawing hand rests at full draw, ensuring consistent aiming.

questions.question: What are 'fletching' (or 'vanes') on an arrow?
options: The painted markings for identification
Metal rings that hold the arrowhead
Decorative wrappings on the shaft
The feathers or plastic fins attached to stabilize the arrow in flight
questions.explanation: Fletching refers to the feathers or plastic vanes attached near the back of an arrow that stabilize it during flight by creating aerodynamic drag and spin.

questions.question: In archery, what is a 'compound bow'?
options: A bow that uses a system of cables and pulleys to reduce holding weight at full draw
A bow made from multiple materials
A bow used in a compound (enclosed area)
Two bows combined into one
questions.explanation: A compound bow uses a system of cables, pulleys (cams), and limbs that provide mechanical advantage, allowing the archer to hold less weight at full draw while storing more energy.

questions.question: What is a 'recurve bow' in archery?
options: A bow designed for left-handed archers
A bow whose limb tips curve away from the archer when unstrung
A bow with a curved handle
A bow that can shoot around corners
questions.explanation: A recurve bow has limbs that curve away from the archer when unstrung, storing more energy and delivering more speed than a simple straight-limbed bow of the same draw weight.

questions.question: In archery, what does 'Robin Hood' refer to?
options: A style of shooting from horseback
Donating arrows to beginners
Wearing a green hat while shooting
Splitting one arrow with another by hitting it in the nock end
questions.explanation: A 'Robin Hood' is when an archer shoots an arrow directly into the end (nock) of another arrow already in the target, splitting or telescoping it, an extremely rare occurrence.

questions.question: What is an 'arm guard' (or 'bracer') used for in archery?
options: Protecting the forearm of the bow arm from the bowstring upon release
Strengthening arm muscles
Keeping the arm steady while aiming
Guarding the arm from sunburn
questions.explanation: An arm guard (bracer) is a protective piece worn on the inside of the bow arm's forearm to prevent the bowstring from slapping the skin upon release.

questions.question: In archery, what is the 'riser'?
options: An elevation platform for the archer
A rising trajectory of the arrow
A device to raise the target higher
The central section of the bow where the grip and arrow rest are located
questions.explanation: The riser is the central, non-bending part of the bow that includes the grip, arrow rest, sight mount, and stabilizer bushing. The limbs attach to the top and bottom of the riser.

questions.question: What is 'archer's paradox'?
options: A philosophical question about archery
The bending of the arrow around the bow upon release, yet still hitting the target
The paradox that heavier arrows fly farther
The contradiction of wanting to hit the target but being nervous
questions.explanation: Archer's paradox is the phenomenon where the arrow bends and flexes around the bow upon release, yet still flies accurately toward the target due to the arrow's natural oscillation.

questions.question: In archery, what is a 'broadhead'?
options: A large target used for practice
A sharp, bladed arrowhead designed for hunting
A wide stance for stability
A wide-brimmed hat worn for sun protection
questions.explanation: A broadhead is a type of arrowhead with sharp blades designed for hunting, engineered to cause a wide wound channel for an ethical, humane harvest.

questions.question: What does 'spine' refer to regarding arrows?
options: The sharp point of the arrowhead
The backbone of the archer
The central line of the target
The stiffness or flexibility of the arrow shaft
questions.explanation: Arrow spine refers to the stiffness of the arrow shaft. Proper spine selection is critical for accuracy, as the arrow must flex appropriately for the bow's draw weight.

questions.question: In archery, what is 'clout shooting'?
options: A competition to see who can shoot the farthest
A form of archery where archers shoot at a flag on the ground from a long distance
Shooting with great force
Shooting while blindfolded
questions.explanation: Clout shooting is a form of archery where competitors shoot arrows at a high arc toward a flag (the clout) on the ground at distances up to 180 yards, scoring based on proximity.
